'''Daniel Pitout''', known professionally as '''Orville Peck''', is a South African [[country music]]ian based in the United States and Canada. He is well-known for wearing a mask and not showing his face publicly.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news |last=Lebar |first=Erin |date=May 25, 2019 |title=Canadian country crooner a man of mystery |url=https://www.winnipegfreepress.com/arts-and-life/entertainment/music/behind-the-mask-510377692.html |url-access=registration |access-date=June 19, 2019 |work=[[Winnipeg Free Press]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.orlandoweekly.com/Blogs/archives/2019/06/12/lonesome-drifter-orville-peck-to-ride-into-orlando-in-september |title=Lonesome drifter Orville Peck rides into Orlando this September |last=Moyer |first=Matthew |website=Orlando Weekly |language=en |access-date=June 20, 2019 |archive-date=June 20, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190620003352/https://www.orlandoweekly.com/Blogs/archives/2019/06/12/lonesome-drifter-orville-peck-to-ride-into-orlando-in-september |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite web |url=https://www.lofficielusa.com/music/orville-peck-interview-2019 |title=Get to Know Orville Peck, Country's Resident Mystery Music Man |date=March 21, 2019 |website=[[L'Officiel]] |access-date=February 26, 2020 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Mier |first=Tomás |date=June 11, 2024 |title=Orville Peck's Mask Keeps Shrinking. He Doesn't 'Know Where It'll End Up' |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/orville-peck-might-get-rid-mask-1235037927/ |access-date=June 14, 2024 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |language=en-US}}</ref>

He released his debut album ''[[Pony (Orville Peck album)|Pony]]'' in 2019,<ref name=":0" /> followed by the EP ''[[Show Pony]]'' the next year. His second studio album ''[[Bronco (Orville Peck album)|Bronco]]'' was released in 2022. Following a self-imposed hiatus in 2023, Peck released his third studio album ''[[Stampede (Orville Peck album)|Stampede]]'' in 2024. 

== Early life ==
Peck was born in [[Johannesburg]], South Africa, and lived there until he was 15.<ref name="appleinterview">{{cite web |title=''Bronco'' by Orville Peck, Liner notes |url=https://music.apple.com/us/album/bronco/1607593873 |publisher=[[Apple Music]] |access-date=April 11, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220409172422/https://music.apple.com/us/album/bronco/1607593873 |archive-date=April 9, 2022 |quote=Everyone thinks I'm Canadian because I lived in Canada for a long time, but I'm not. I was born in South Africa—I grew up in Johannesburg until I was 15. I never talked about where I was from only because I wanted to wait—obviously, I'm a man of mystery and I like to not give everyone everything all at once. ... There's a sense of guilt and regret in the song about leaving somewhere that you don't really want to leave because you have to go make your way in the world. I'm so proud to be South African. I go back there all the time. }}</ref> As a child, he taught himself music by playing an acoustic guitar and an old [[Casio]] keyboard.<ref>{{Cite web |author1=Jacob Uitti |date=August 14, 2020 |title=Orville Peck: "I learned to play guitar without the high E string - I didn't know how to change it when it broke!" |url=https://www.guitarworld.com/features/orville-peck-i-learned-to-play-guitar-without-the-high-e-string-i-didnt-know-how-to-change-it-when-it-broke |access-date=March 11, 2022 |website=guitarworld |language=en}}</ref> He is the son of a sound engineer, and he did [[voice-over]] work for cartoons and other media as a child.<ref name=":u">{{Cite web|url=https://foreverdogpodcasts.com/podcasts/sloppy-seconds/|title=Bamboozlement (w/ Orville Peck)|date=May 1, 2020|work=Sloppy Seconds with Big Dipper & Meatball|language=en|format=Podcast|via=foreverdogpodcasts.com|access-date=July 12, 2020}}</ref> Growing up, he took ballet classes for 12 years, and performed in musical theatre productions. By the time he was in his early 20s, he had been on national tours of musicals.<ref name=":u" />

Peck moved to London for a [[foundation degree]] in acting from the [[London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art]] in 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.straight.com/music/716231/nu-sensae-goes-hiatus-daniel-pitout-goes-england|title=Nü Sensae goes on hiatus, Daniel Pitout goes to England|date=August 27, 2014|website=The Georgia Straight|accessdate=April 30, 2024}}</ref> He then played Jonathan Harris/[[Peter Pan]] in the [[Mischief Theatre]] production of ''[[Peter Pan Goes Wrong]]'' at the [[Apollo Theatre]] in 2016.<ref>{{Cite web |date=November 9, 2016 |title=Photos: New Cast of 'Peter Pan Goes Wrong' Walks the Plank in the West End |url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/westend/article/Photo-Flash-New-Cast-of-PETER-PAN-GOES-WRONG-Walks-the-Plank-in-the-West-End-20161109 |accessdate=April 30, 2024 |website=BroadwayWorld}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Production of Peter Pan Goes Wrong |url=https://theatricalia.com/play/egs/peter-pan-goes-wrong/production/xf6 |accessdate=April 30, 2024 |website=Theatricalia}}</ref>

== Career ==
[[File:Orville Peck - First Avenue - 6-5-2022 - 012 (cropped).jpg|thumb|Peck performing in 2022]]
Peck self-produced his debut album, ''Pony'', and released it in 2019 through a collaboration with [[Sub Pop]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.vogue.com/vogueworld/article/orville-peck-masked-country-music-musician-born-to-die|title=Meet Orville Peck, Country Music's Anonymous Masked Musician|last=Satenstein|first=Liana|website=Vogue|date=June 13, 2019|language=en|access-date=June 19, 2019}}</ref> He has noted that he "wrote, produced and played every instrument he could" on the album while working in a coffee shop and living with his parents.<ref>{{Cite tweet|last=Peck|first=Orville|title= Speechless... thank you.|date=June 15, 2020|user=orvillepeck|number=1272573115998982144|access-date=June 19, 2020}}</ref> In June of that year, he performed his songs "Dead of Night" and "Take You Back" live on [[CBC Radio One]]'s ''[[Q (radio show)|Q]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbc.ca/radio/q/friday-june-14-2019-orville-peck-joe-namath-and-more-1.5173801/meet-orville-peck-the-masked-country-music-star-1.5173815|title=Meet Orville Peck, the masked country music star|website=[[CBC Music]]|publisher=[[Radio Canada]]|date=June 14, 2019|access-date=June 19, 2020}}</ref> ''Pony'' was named to the initial longlist for the [[2019 Polaris Music Prize]] in June 2019.<ref name="longlist" /> The album also received a [[Juno Award]] nomination for [[Juno Award for Alternative Album of the Year|Alternative Album of the Year]] at the [[Juno Awards of 2020]].<ref name="Juno Awards 2020">{{Cite web|first=Melody|last=Lau|url=https://www.cbc.ca/music/junos/news/alessia-cara-and-tory-lanez-lead-the-2020-juno-nominations-1.5436386|title=Alessia Cara and Tory Lanez lead the 2020 Juno nominations|website=[[CBC Music]]|publisher=[[Radio Canada]]|date=January 28, 2019|access-date=June 19, 2020}}</ref>

Peck performed "Dead of Night" on ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live]]'' on January 29, 2020.<ref name=freeman>{{Cite magazine|first=Jon|last=Freeman|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/orville-peck-dead-of-night-kimmel-pony-945470|title=Orville Peck Performs 'Dead of Night' on 'Kimmel'|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=January 30, 2020|access-date=June 19, 2020}}</ref> He also announced a tour of selected cities in the United States, including performances at the [[Coachella]] and [[Stagecoach Festival|Stagecoach]] festivals.<ref name=freeman/>

In May 2020, Peck announced the follow-up to his debut album, an [[Extended play|EP]] titled ''Show Pony'', with a release date of June 12, 2020. In June 2020, Peck announced the delayed release of ''Show Pony'' until August 14, 2020, in recognition of the [[Black Lives Matter]] movement and the [[George Floyd protests]].<ref name="NME Show Pony Delay" /><ref name="Rolling Stone: Show Pony" />

Peck recorded a cover of "[[Smalltown Boy]]" for the 2020 Pride edition of the [[Spotify Singles|Spotify Singles series]]. The song was released exclusively on [[Spotify]] on June 29, 2020, and everywhere else on July 31, 2020.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Listen to Orville Peck cover Bronski Beat's '80s anthem 'Smalltown Boy'|first=Michael|last=Marotta|url=https://vanyaland.com/2020/06/29/listen-to-orville-peck-cover-bronski-beats-80s-anthem-smalltown-boy/|website=Vanyaland|date=June 29, 2020|access-date=July 31, 2020}}</ref>

In April 2021, Peck was featured on American drag queen and singer [[Trixie Mattel]]'s EP, ''[[Full Coverage, Vol. 1]]''. He appeared on a duet cover of [[Johnny Cash]] and [[June Carter Cash]]'s "[[Jackson (song)|Jackson]]".<ref>{{Cite web|last=Curran|first=Sarah|date=April 30, 2021|title=Orville Peck And Trixie Mattel Team Up For Foot Stomping Cover Of 'Jackson'|url=https://etcanada.com/news/775465/orville-peck-and-trixie-mattel-team-up-for-foot-stomping-cover-of-jackson/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210430211051/https://etcanada.com/news/775465/orville-peck-and-trixie-mattel-team-up-for-foot-stomping-cover-of-jackson/|url-status=dead|archive-date=April 30, 2021|access-date=April 30, 2021|website=ET Canada|language=en-US}}</ref> Although not credited in the liner notes for the EP, [[Trixie Mattel]] has confirmed that the whistle part in "[[Video Games (Lana Del Rey song)|Video Games]]" is Peck's whistle.<ref>{{Citation |title=ORVILLE PECK Does Trixie's Makeup! | date=May 29, 2023 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LYyIVOMp8oI |access-date=May 30, 2023 |language=en}}</ref> In June, he was revealed to be the sixth artist on [[Lady Gaga]]'s ''[[Born This Way The Tenth Anniversary]]'', with Peck reimagining the song "[[Born This Way (song)|Born This Way]]" in a country style.<ref>Allie Gregory, [https://exclaim.ca/music/article/orville_peck_turns_lady_gagas_born_this_way_into_a_country_anthem "Orville Peck Turns Lady Gaga's "Born This Way" into a Country Anthem"]. ''[[Exclaim!]]'', June 4, 2021.</ref>

On March 16, 2023, Peck made an appearance as a guest on the judge's panel on [[MTV]]'s ''[[RuPaul's Drag Race]]'', alongside [[RuPaul Charles]], [[Michelle Visage]], and [[Ross Mathews]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wegotthiscovered.com/tv/heres-every-celebrity-guest-judge-for-rupauls-drag-race-season-15 |title=Here's every celebrity guest judge for 'RuPaul's Drag Race' season 15 |author= Raschella, Cody |date=December 20, 2022 |accessdate=March 15, 2023 |website=WeGotThisCovered.com}}</ref> In 2023, Peck was a coach and judge on [[My Kind of Country (2023 TV series)|''My Kind of Country'']].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Liptak |first=Carena|date=April 5, 2023 |title=Jimmie Allen, Mickey Guyton + Orville Peck Lead a Wave of Outsiders on 'My Kind of Country' |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/jimmie-allen-mickey-guyton-orville-peck-my-kind-of-country/ |access-date=July 15, 2023 |website=Taste of Country |language=en}}</ref>

On April 5, 2024, Peck released a cover of [[Ned Sublette]]'s "[[Cowboys Are Frequently, Secretly Fond of Each Other]]" with country musician [[Willie Nelson]] as the lead single from ''[[Stampede (Orville Peck album)|Stampede]]'', Peck's third studio album and first duets album. The single marked his first release on [[Warner Records]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Strauss |first1=Matthew |title=Orville Peck Announces Tour, Shares New Video With Willie Nelson: Watch |url=https://pitchfork.com/news/orville-peck-announces-tour-shares-new-video-with-willie-nelson-watch/ |website=Pitchfork |date=April 5, 2024 |access-date=April 5, 2024}}</ref> Peck also announced a headlining North American tour, The Stampede Tour, which began on May 28, 2024, in [[Asheville, North Carolina]].<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Mier |first1=Tomás |title=Orville Peck Announces Expansive Stampede Tour Ahead of Willie Nelson Collab |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/orville-peck-stampede-tour-willie-nelson-collab-1234997614/ |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=April 2, 2024 |access-date=April 5, 2024}}</ref> In May 2024, Peck released the duet "How Far Will We Take It?" with [[Noah Cyrus]]. On 7 June 2024, Peck released the single "[[Midnight Ride (song)|Midnight Ride]]" alongside [[Kylie Minogue]] and [[Diplo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://open.spotify.com/track/2BFnfCnAW6O1a1vZ8NZvkO?si=a363340e9fec4123|title=Midnight Ride - Orville Peck, Kylie Minogue, Diplo|website=Spotify|date=7 June 2024|access-date=17 August 2024}}</ref>

==Artistry==
===Identity===
It has been confirmed that Orville Peck is a persona of Daniel Pitout, drummer of the Canadian punk band [[Nü Sensae]].<ref name="birth-name-info">{{Cite web |last=Caporale |first=Micco |date=April 6, 2022 |title=When Orville Peck's mask came off, his walls went up |url=http://chicagoreader.com/music/orville-peck-bronco-daniel-pitout/ |access-date=November 17, 2022 |website=Chicago Reader |language=en-US}}</ref> It was previously speculated that Pitout was Peck based on the similarity of their tattoos,<ref name="Hagwood2019">{{Cite news|last=Hagwood|first=Alex|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/12/style/orville-peck-a-masked-gay-country-music.html|title=Orville Peck, a Masked Gay Country Star, Rides Into Brooklyn|date=October 12, 2019|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=January 30, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Saxberg|first=Lynn|url=https://ottawacitizen.com/entertainment/local-arts/meet-orville-peck-the-mysterious-new-country-artist-who-plays-in-ottawa-thursday|title=Meet Orville Peck, the mysterious new country artist who plays in Ottawa Thursday|website=[[Ottawa Citizen]]|date=April 10, 2019|access-date=June 19, 2020}}</ref> and Peck's mentioning that he was in a punk band. Pitout was born in [[Johannesburg]], South Africa,<ref name=":y">{{Cite news|first=Eric|last=Torres|url=http://gayletter.com/eating-out-with-daniel-pitout/|title=Eating Out with Daniel Pitout|work=[[Gayletter]]|access-date=July 12, 2020}}</ref> as was Peck.<ref name="appleinterview"/>  Pitout is also listed by [[ASCAP]] as the songwriter for Peck's song "Old River"<ref>{{cite web|publisher=ASCAP|url=https://www.ascap.com/repertory#/ace/search/workID/907512330|title=Old River song info|access-date=December 23, 2021}}</ref> and other songs that match the titles of the songs released by Peck, such as "Roses Are Falling".<ref>{{cite web|publisher=ASCAP|url=https://www.ascap.com/repertory#/ace/search/workID/910540431|title=Roses Are Falling song info|access-date=December 23, 2021}}</ref>

===Influences===
Peck strongly identifies with 1970s era country music and lists classic stars [[Merle Haggard]], [[Waylon Jennings]], [[George Jones]], [[Tammy Wynette]], [[Johnny Cash]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[Gram Parsons]], [[Emmylou Harris]], [[Bobbie Gentry]], [[Reba McEntire]] and [[Dolly Parton]] as influences. Outside of country music, Peck has mentioned [[Roy Orbison]], [[Oasis (band)|Oasis]], [[Whitney Houston]] and [[Lana Del Rey]] and film directors [[David Lynch]] and [[John Waters]] as influences.<ref>{{cite web|work=[[NME]]|url=https://www.nme.com/big-reads/orville-peck-cover-interview-2020-female-rappers-like-doja-cat-have-a-lot-of-cowboy-energy-2640216|title=Orville Peck: "Female rappers like Doja Cat have a lot of cowboy energy"|date=April 3, 2020 |access-date=April 3, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[Loud and Quiet]]|url=https://www.loudandquiet.com/interview/orville-peck-the-outlaw-country-singer-who-believes-effort-is-king/|title=Orville Peck – The outlaw country singer who believes effort is king|access-date=February 25, 2019}}</ref>

== Personal life ==
Peck is gay.<ref name="Hagwood2019" /><ref>{{Cite web|title=Masked country king Orville Peck would like his own version of The Bachelor|url=https://www.thefader.com/2019/06/19/orville-peck-would-you-rather-video|access-date=June 19, 2019|website=[[The Fader]]|language=en}}</ref> Regarding his reasons for wearing a mask to perform, he has stated: "The only reason I don't talk about it in depth is not because I want to dodge any questions, but because I want people to have their own take on it. I don't want to lay it out and pin it down. I just don't think that's important."<ref>{{Cite web|first=Amy|last=Campbell|url=https://www.gq.com.au/entertainment/music/queer-cowboy-orville-peck-is-redefining-country-music-for-a-new-generation-of-fans/image-gallery/6d4cbba51f16a1bb89c45e5e399d8cd0|title=Queer Cowboy Orville Peck Is Redefining Country Music For A New Generation Of Fans|website=[[GQ Australia]]|date=January 16, 2020|access-date=September 29, 2020}}</ref>

In 2022, Peck's home was featured and toured by [[Architectural Digest]].<ref>{{Cite web |date=November 7, 2023 |title=Tour Country Star Orville Peck's Los Angeles Tree House |url=https://www.architecturaldigest.com/story/tour-country-star-orville-pecks-los-angeles-tree-house |access-date=March 4, 2024 |website=Architectural Digest |language=en-US}}</ref> The video was released on November 6, 2023, with the article released on November 7, 2023. {{As of|July 2024}}, Peck resides in Los Angeles.<ref name="e!">{{Cite magazine |issn=1207-6600 |language=en-CA |magazine=[[Exclaim!]] |accessdate=July 3, 2024 |date=July 3, 2024 |url=https://exclaim.ca/music/article/orville-peck-interview-stampede-questionnaire |title=Orville Peck on Loving Dolly, Being Buddies with John Waters and Getting Unmasked by Bebe Rexha |first=Laura |last=Stanley}}</ref>

|}

In June 2020, in honor of the 50th anniversary of the first LGBTQ [[Pride parade]], ''[[Queerty]]'' named him among the fifty heroes "leading the nation toward equality, acceptance, and dignity for all people".<ref>{{Cite web |title=Queerty Pride50 2020 Honorees |url=https://www.queerty.com/pride50/ |access-date=June 30, 2020 |website=[[Queerty]] |language=en-US }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Tracer |first=Daniel |date=July 15, 2020 |title=These musicians became queer role models young fans need, and they're changing the world for good |url=https://www.queerty.com/musicians-became-queer-role-models-young-fans-need-theyre-changing-world-good-20200715 |access-date=August 2, 2020 |website=[[Queerty]] }}</ref>

In June 2022, Peck was presented with the Cultural Icon Award by the [[Tom of Finland Foundation]], "for artistic achievement and immeasurable contributions to the art and culture of our community", an award previously presented to [[Rob Halford]], [[Henry Rollins]], [[Clive Barker]] and [[John Waters]].<ref>{{cite AV media |date=June 19, 2022 |title=Orville Peck: Tom of Finland Foundation 2022 Cultural Icon Award winner |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NoCOSajAqOE |access-date=July 4, 2022 |publisher=[[Tom of Finland Foundation]] |via=YouTube }}</ref>
